Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: This morning, as I was heading out to work, my dog started barking loudly in the hallway just as Mrs. Lee from next door passed by. She shot me a look—half annoyance, half exhaustion. I know the walls are thin, and everyone expects me to keep things quiet and respectful, especially in shared spaces. I apologized, tugging my dog back inside, but I could feel the tension simmering. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my supervisor: “The machines in sector B are overheating. Need urgent maintenance.” I’m the only one on shift today, and if I don’t get to those machines soon, we risk a breakdown. But if I leave now, my dog will be alone, likely barking at every sound, disturbing the neighbors even more. I’m torn—do I rush to the machines and risk upsetting everyone on my floor, or do I stay and calm my dog, knowing the machines could fail? The weight of both responsibilities presses on me, and I stand frozen in the hallway, caught between being a good neighbor and a reliable repairer.
